Fast Bayesian marginal likelihood for the Normal - Inverted Wishart model.

Implemented in C. See diwishart_inverse for the parametrization of the Inverted Wishart. See marginalLikelihood_internal for further documentation.

marginalLikelihood(X, n.iter, B.inv, W.inv, U, nw, mu, burn.in,
  output.mcmc = FALSE, verbose = FALSE, Gibbs_only = FALSE, n_cores = 1)

Arguments

X

the dataset
n.iter

number of MC iterations
B.inv

prior inverse of between covariance matrix
W.inv

prior inverse of within covariance matrix
U

covariance matrix for the mean
nw

degrees of freedom
mu

prior mean
burn.in

burn-in iterations
output.mcmc

output the entire chain
verbose

if TRUE, be verbose
Gibbs_only

if TRUE, only return the Gibbs posterior samples. Implies chain_output = TRUE.
n_cores

if > 1, use OpenMP on the specified amount of cores (experimental).

Value

the log-marginal likelihood value, or a list(the log-ml value, coda object with the posterior samples)

Normal-Inverse-Wishart model[1]

Observation level: $$X_{ij} ~ N(theta_i, W_i)$$ (i = population, j = items in population)

Group level: $$theta_i ~ N(\mu, B)$$ $$W_i ~ IW(nw, U)$$

Hyperparameters: \(B, U, nw, \mu\)

A Gibbs sampler supplies theta, W^(-1).

Inverted Wishart parametrization (Press)

Uses Press[1] parametrization. $$X ~ IW(v, S)$$, with \(S = pxp\) matrix, \(v > 2p\) (the degrees of freedom). Then: $$E[X] = S / (v - 2(p + 1))$$

References

[1]S. Bozza, F. Taroni, R. Marquis, and M. Schmittbuhl, “Probabilistic evaluation of handwriting evidence: likelihood ratio for authorship,” Journal of the Royal Statistical Society: Series C (Applied Statistics), vol. 57, no. 3, pp. 329–341, Jun. 2008.

[1]S. J. Press, Applied multivariate analysis: using Bayesian and frequentist methods of inference. Courier Corporation, 2012.
